persons.name: JohnLeslie
persons.description: Scottish mathematician and physicist, Professor of Mathematics at Edinburgh University, best known for his research into heat.

persons.name: BenjaminThompson
persons.description: Born in Massachusetts, he served in the British and Bavarian armies. Knighted by George III in 1787, the Elector of Bavaria created him Reichsgraf von Rumford of the Holy Roman Empire in 1792. His appointment in the late 1790s as Bavarian ambassador to London created a minor diplomatic incident, during which he helped establish and manage the Royal Institution, in the course of which he appointed Davy to lecture there. Later he married Lavoisier's widow and lived unhappily ever after. FRSL.

places.name: Paros
places.description: A Greek island situated in the Mediterranean Sea, famous for its Parian marble: a fine-grained semi translucent pure-white and entirely flawless marble quarried during the classical era .

persons.name: BenjaminThompson
persons.description: Born in Massachusetts, he served in the British and Bavarian armies. Knighted by George III in 1787, the Elector of Bavaria created him Reichsgraf von Rumford of the Holy Roman Empire in 1792. His appointment in the late 1790s as Bavarian ambassador to London created a minor diplomatic incident, during which he helped establish and manage the Royal Institution, in the course of which he appointed Davy to lecture there. Later he married Lavoisier's widow and lived unhappily ever after. FRSL.

persons.name: JohnLeslie
persons.description: Scottish mathematician and physicist, Professor of Mathematics at Edinburgh University, best known for his research into heat.

persons.name: IsaacNewton
persons.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

persons.name: Frederick WilliamHerschel
persons.description: Hanoverian astronomer and composer who while living in Bath discovered the planet later named Uranus. Moving to Slough he built the world's largest telescope to date which Davy visited when he was courting Jane Apreece. FRSL.

persons.name: Frederick WilliamHerschel
persons.description: Hanoverian astronomer and composer who while living in Bath discovered the planet later named Uranus. Moving to Slough he built the world's largest telescope to date which Davy visited when he was courting Jane Apreece. FRSL.

persons.name: PierrePrevost
persons.description: A Genevan philosopher and physicist. In 1791 he explained Pictet's experiment by arguing that all bodies radiate heat, no matter how hot or cold they are.

persons.name: Frederick WilliamHerschel
persons.description: Hanoverian astronomer and composer who while living in Bath discovered the planet later named Uranus. Moving to Slough he built the world's largest telescope to date which Davy visited when he was courting Jane Apreece. FRSL.

persons.name: Marc-AugustePictet
persons.description: Genevan natural philosopher and journal editor. Corresponded with Davy. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: JamesHutton
persons.description: Scottish geologist, agriculturalist and chemical manufacturer. His Theory of the Earth (1795) is one of the foundations of modern geology. Davy discussed Hutton's theories in his lectures and visited some of the key geological sites that Hutton used in his work.

persons.name: JohnFoster
persons.description: From 1821, first Baron Oriel. Irish politician serving in the Dublin and then Westminster parliaments. Vice President of the Dublin Society where Davy lectured in 1810 and 1811. FRSL.

persons.name: Epicurus
persons.description: Ancient Greek philosopher, an atomist and materialist, following in the steps of Democritus and founder of Epicureanism.

persons.name: Benoitde Maillet
persons.description: French natural philosopher who presented controversial evolutionary speculations.

persons.name: Heraclitus
persons.description: An ancient Greek pre-Socratic philosopher from the city of Ephesus, which was then part of the Persian Empire.

persons.name: JohnLeslie
persons.description: Scottish mathematician and physicist, Professor of Mathematics at Edinburgh University, best known for his research into heat.

persons.name: EdwardLisle
persons.description: Barrister of Moyles Court, Hampshire, who contributed significantly to Observations in Husbandry (1757) which his son published posthumously.

places.name: Rhine
places.description: The Rhine is one of Europe's major rivers. It rises in Switzerland, flows through Germany, and enters the North Sea in the Netherlands.

places.name: Alps
places.description: The Alps are the highest and most extensive mountain range that lies entirely in Europe. They are located in eight European countries.

places.name: Tyrol
places.description: Tyrol is a historical region in the Alps located in northern Italy and western Austria.

places.name: River Danube
places.description: The Danube is the second longest river in Europe. It flows through central and south eastern Europe into the Black Sea.

persons.name: Georges-Louis Leclerc, Comte deBuffon
persons.description: French naturalist, mathematician and cosmologist. His Histoire Naturelle, published in 1789, ran to 37 volumes. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: EdwardLisle
persons.description: Barrister of Moyles Court, Hampshire, who contributed significantly to Observations in Husbandry (1757) which his son published posthumously.

persons.name: Jean SylvainBailly
persons.description: French astronomer, mathematician, and political leader of the early part of the French Revolution.

persons.name: William HydeWollaston
persons.description: Originally a physician he became a prominent chemist, physicist and physiologist isolating the chemical elements osmium, palladium and rhodium. He made his fortune by developing a method of obtaining metallic platinum. A friend and to some extent a rival of Davy's, in 1820 he served briefly as President of the Royal Society of London between Banks's death and Davy's election. FRSL.

persons.name: Johann WilhelmRitter
persons.description: German physician and natural philosopher.

persons.name: Lucretius
persons.description: Roman poet and philosopher. His only known work is the materialist philosophical poem De rerum natura.

places.name: New Holland
places.description: New Holland was the name first given to Australia by the Dutch seafarer, Abel Tasman.

persons.name: Jean-BaptisteBiot
persons.description: French mathematician, physicist and astronomer; Professor of Physics at the Collège de France. ForMemRSL.

persons.name: JohnDalton
persons.description: Mancunian chemist and natural philosopher who lectured at the Royal Institution. He formulated a version of the atomic theory of matter much disliked by Davy. FRSL.

places.name: Lakes of Killarney
places.description: Three lakes (Lough Leane, Muckross Lake - also called Middle Lake, and Upper Lake) surrounded by the MacGillycuddy's Reeks and now part of Killarney National Park.

places.name: Croghan
places.description: Crohane, a mountain in County Kerry. In Irish, it's called An Cruachán.

persons.name: FrancisBacon
persons.description: English lawyer, politician and natural philosopher. His influential writings encouraged experimentation and the use of induction in investigating the natural world. He also recommended establishing institutions to promote collaborative research.

persons.name: IsaacNewton
persons.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.

persons.name: JamesThomson
persons.description: A Scottish poet and playwright, known for his poems The Seasons and The Castle of Indolence, and for the lyrics of "Rule, Britannia!"

persons.name: IsaacNewton
persons.description: Prominent English natural philosopher and mathematician greatly admired by Davy who once under the influence of several litres of nitrous oxide wrote in his notebook 'Davy & Newton' in one inch letters. FRSL.
